sentence:
(CHHM¬†<cit.>).
A distribution Œº on J(P) is called toggle-symmetric if for each p ‚àà P the probability that p can be toggled into I is equal to the probability that it can be toggled out of I when I ‚àºŒº. In other words, Œº is toggle-symmetric if ùîº(Œº;ùíØ^+_p ) = ùîº(Œº;ùíØ^-_p) for all p ‚àà P.

sentence: We say that a distributive lattice J(P) is toggle-CDE ( tCDE ) if ùîº(Œº;ddeg)=ùîº(uni_J(P);ddeg) for every toggle-symmetric distribution Œº on¬†J(P).

sentence:
(See Reiner-Tenner-Yong¬†<cit.>).
Let Œª/ŒΩ be a skew shape. A set-valued filling T of shape Œª/ŒΩ is an assignment to each box u of¬†Œª/ŒΩ of a finite, nonempty subset  T(u)‚äÜ{1,2,‚Ä¶}. To any set-valued filling T we associate the monomial

    ùê±^T := ‚àè_u ‚ààŒª/ŒΩ ‚àè_i ‚àà T(u) x_i.

We define |T| to be the degree of ùê±^T. A set-valued tableau[Sometimes these tableaux are called column-strict or semi-standard . We will not use these adjectives as all tableaux will be assumed to be column-strict.] T of shape Œª/ŒΩ is a set-valued filling T satisfying


  * max T(u) ‚â§min  T(v) if v is east of and in the same row as u;

  * max T(u) < min  T(v) if v is south of and in the same column as u.

This T is standard if ùê±^T = x_1x_2‚ãØ x_N for some N. We say that T is simply a tableau if¬†#T(u)=1 for all boxes u of Œª/ŒΩ, while we say that T is barely set-valued if #T(u)=1 for all boxes u of Œª/ŒΩ except for a unique u_0 which has #T(u_0) = 2.

sentence:
(Ikeda and Naruse¬†<cit.>).
Let Œª be a strict partition. A shifted set-valued filling T of shape Œª is an assignment to each box u of¬†P^shift_Œª of a finite, nonempty subset  T(u)‚äÜ{1,1',2,2',‚Ä¶}. Here the set of unprimed and primed positive integers is given the total order 1 < 1' < 2 < 2' < ‚ãØ. To any such set-valued filling T we associate the monomial

    ùê±^T := ‚àè_u ‚àà P_Œª^shift( ‚àè_i ‚àà T(u) x_i ) ( ‚àè_i' ‚àà T(u) x_i ).

We define |T| to be the degree of ùê±^T. A shifted set-valued tableau T of shape Œª is a set-valued filling T satisfying


  * max T(u) ‚â§min  T(v) for all u ‚â§ v ‚àà P_Œª^shift;

  * each unprimed integer appears at most once in each column;

  * each primed integer appears at most once in each row.

This T is standard if ùê±^T = x_1x_2‚ãØ x_N for some N. We say that T is simply a shifted tableau if¬†#T(u)=1 for all boxes u of Œª/ŒΩ, while we say that T is barely set-valued if #T(u)=1 for all boxes u of Œª/ŒΩ except for a unique u_0 which has #T(u_0) = 2. We say that T is unprimed if no primed integers appear in T, while we say that T is diagonally unprimed if no primed integers appear in main diagonal boxes in T.

Let us recall that a poset P is bipartite if its
comparability graph G(P) is bipartite; equivalently P is the union

maximal elements.

sentence: For t‚àà{ 1,2,‚Ä¶, n-1 }, a Schr√∂der path p ‚ààùíÆ_n which contains an occurrence of  joining (t-1,t) to (t,t+1) is said to have a level feature at t, and a Schr√∂der path p‚ààùíÆ_n which contains an occurrence of  joining points (t-1,t) to (t,t) to (t,t+1) is said to have a notch feature at t. A Schr√∂der path p‚ààùíÆ_n is said to have a feature at t‚àà{ 1,2,‚Ä¶, n-1 } if it has either a level feature or a notch feature at t.

sentence:
Let T be a tree, let f be a graceful labeling of T, let v_1, ‚Ä¶ , v_m be a sequence of vertices of T, and let a, b, c, d be integers.  We say that (T, f, v_1, ‚Ä¶ , v_m, a, b, c, d) is a transfer context if the following conditions hold:


  * The labels of v_1, ‚Ä¶ , v_m, in order, are

    a,  b - 1,  a + 1,  b - 2,‚Ä¶    or     a,  b + 1,  a - 1,  b + 2,‚Ä¶


  * v_1 is adjacent to leaves with labels c,   c + 1, ‚Ä¶ ,  d.

(v_1 may also be adjacent to other leaves.)

  * a + b = c + d.

(This ensures that the labels of the leaves at v_1 are the same as if the leaves were just transferred from a previous vertex v_0 with label b.)

sentence:
Given a transfer context (T, f, v_1, ‚Ä¶ , v_m, a, b, c, d), a well-behaved sequence of transfers is a finite sequence of transfers

    v_i_1‚Üí v_i_2‚Üí‚ãØ‚Üí v_i_k

with i_1 = 1, such that


  * All transfers are type-1 transfers.

  * The set of leaves transferred in the first step is a subset of the set of leaves {c,‚Ä¶ , d}.  The set of leaves transferred in each subsequent step is a subset of the leaves transferred in the previous step.

  * Each transfer v_i_j‚Üí v_i_j + 1 has indices i_j, i_j + 1 of different parity.

The result of a well-behaved sequence of transfers is the sequence n_1, ‚Ä¶ , n_m of non-negative integers, such that after performing the transfers, each v_k is adjacent to n_k of the leaves c,‚Ä¶ , d originally adjacent to v_1.

sentence:
Let D be a digraph.
The digraph D^r has the same vertex set as D, and the arcs from vertex a to vertex b are in bijection with the set of (a,b)-walks in D of length r.
The digraph D^r is called the r power of D .

sentence:
A node k in G is said to be freely removable if removing k from G





  (a) does not create a sink in G‚àñ{k} and




  (b) does not create a target-free 3-cycle in G‚àñ{k} if k was otherwise a target of that 3-cycle.




We say a graph G is irreducible if it is cyclically symmetric or has no freely removable nodes.  If G is cyclically symmetric, it is also called a core cycle .

sentence: Suppose k, d are positive integers with k<d. Let W_d be the set of words on alphabet {0,1} of length d and first letter 1. For w = w_1w_2 ‚Ä¶ w_d in W_d, we may write w as a concatenation of subwords w = B_1(w)B_2(w) ‚Ä¶ B_q(w) where B_i(w) is a word of all 1's if i is odd and all 0's if i is even. We will call these the blocks of w. For any 1 ‚â§ j ‚â§ d, let b_j(w) be the index of the block of w containing w_j.  Let W_d(k) denote the set of words in W_d with exactly k+1 blocks.

sentence:
Let X be a smooth subvariety of a torus ^r, and let
  X be a normal and -factorial compactification
  containing X as a dense open subvariety. Let ‚àÇX = X‚àñ X be the boundary
  divisor of X.  We say that this boundary is a
  combinatorial normal crossings divisor if for every integer
  l, and any choice of l boundary components, their intersection
  has codimension l. Similarly, the boundary is a simple
    normal crossings divisor if, in addition, this intersection is
  transverse (i.e. the intersection behaves locally like a hyperplane
  arrangement).  We say that (X,‚àÇX) is
  a combinatorial normal crossing pair or cnc pair for
  short, if the boundary is a combinatorial normal crossing
  divisor. Simple normal crossing pairs ( snc pairs for
  short) are defined analogously.

sentence:
A triple of type A is an arrangement of boxes, a, b, c,
located such that a is immediately to the left of b, and c is somewhere below b,
and the row containing a and b is at least as long as the row containing c.

Similarly, a triple of type B is an arrangement of boxes, a, b, c,
located such that a is immediately to the left of b, and c is somewhere above a,
and the row containing a and b is strictly longer than the row containing c.


A type A triple is an inversion triple if the entries ordered increasingly,
form a counter-clockwise orientation. Similarly, a type B triple is an inversion triple
if the entries ordered increasingly form a clockwise orientation.
If two entries are equal, the one with largest subscript in <ref>
is considered largest.

       [‚ãÆ] 
        c_2 
        Type B:  centertableaux,boxsize=1.2em
    c_2    
    [‚ãÆ]     
    
    a_3     b_1

sentence: Let S be a numerical semigroup.  The elements of the complement ‚àñ S are called the gaps of S.  The largest of these gaps is called the Frobenius number of S, denoted F(S).  The number of gaps is called the genus of S, denoted g(S).

sentence:
Let S be a numerical semigroup of genus g.  The effective generators of S are the elements of its minimal generating set that are larger than F(S).  The number of effective generators of S is called the efficacy of S, denoted h(S).

The children of a numerical semigroup S of genus g are the numerical semigroups of genus g+1 that come from removing an effective generator from S.  The number of children of S is h(S).

sentence:
Let S be a numerical semigroup.  An effective generator Œª is strong if m(S) + Œª is a minimal generator of S ‚àñ{Œª}.  An effective generator that is not strong is a weak generator .

We say that S' descends from S if S' = S ‚àñ{Œª} for some effective generator Œª of S.  This descent is strong if Œª is a strong generator of S and we say that S' is a strongly descended numerical semigroup.  A descent that is not strong is a weak descent .  We say that S‚Äù is a weak descendant of S if S‚Äù is obtained from S by a series of weak descents.

sentence:
A shadow or diagram D is prime if it has more than 1
  vertex and is not 2-edge-connected, i.e. there is no way to
  disconnect D by removing 2 edges. A shadow or diagram
  which is not prime is composite . A rooted shadow or diagram
  is two-leg-prime if it cannot be disconnected by removing two
  edges, one being the root edge .

  A shadow or diagram D is reduced if it has no
  disconnecting vertices ( i.e. , isthmi).

sentence:
A map with n vertices M is a graph M embedded on a
  (usually oriented) surface  so that every connected component of
  ‚àñ M is a topological disk. The connected components of
  ‚àñ M are called the faces of M. If 
  is the oriented sphere, then the map M is planar . As each face must
  be a disk, maps' underlying graphs are necessarily connected.

  A map M is 4-regular , 4-valent , or quartic if every
  vertex in the underlying graph M has degree 4.

sentence:
A rooted map is a map together with a single edge marked with
  a direction, called a root edge .

  An automorphism of a rooted map M would be required to fix the
  root edge, its direction, and the orientation of the surface near
  the root; hence (M) is the trivial group.

sentence:
A map P with distinguished exterior face of k-edges is a
  submap of a larger (possibly rooted) map M if there
  exists a cycle of k (possibly repeated) edges in M so that
  one of the two halves of M separated by the cycle is identical
  to P.

  diagram D is an equivalence class of edges modulo meeting across

  knot universes¬†<cit.>.] is a link shadow which
  consists of precisely one link component. The class of knot shadows
  with n crossings is denoted by _n.

  A knot diagram is a link diagram which
  consists of precisely one link component. The class of knot diagrams
  with n crossings is denoted by _n.

  degree 2k. A 2k-tangle diagram is an unrooted

  the exterior vertex), is a submap of D^*; for diagrams it is furthermore
  required that the signs of the crossings agree.

sentence:
Let Q be a tangle diagram,  some class of diagrams,
  and ‚Ñã a subclass of . A viable
    attachment of the tangle Q into ‚Ñã is a method
  of taking a diagram D ‚àà‚Ñã and producing new
  diagrams D' that contain Q as a subtangle satisfying:
  
  
  * For some fixed positive integer k, at least
    ‚åä e(D)/k ‚åã possible non-conflicting places of
    attachment exist. This means that at least
    ‚åä e(D)/k ‚åã attachment operations (of Q) to a
    single diagram can be ‚Äúparallelized‚Äù and all performed at once
    to a diagram to produce a new diagram with at least
    ‚åä e(D)/k ‚åã copies of Q contained as subtangles.
  
  * Only diagrams in  are produced ( is
    closed under attachments of Q).
  
  * For any diagram produced as such we can identify the copies of
    Q that have been added and they are all pairwise vertex
    disjoint. Identifying tangles in diagrams is trivial since a
    diagram contains a tangle if there is some dual cycle whose
    interior is the tangle itself. We will consider only Q which
    are always pairwise disjoint, and hence any attachment
    would satisfy the latter half of this condition.
  
  * Given the copies of Q that have been added, the original
    diagram and associated places of attachment are uniquely
    determined. For our attachments, we will provide suitable
    ‚Äúinverse‚Äù operations which are themselves parallelizable (since
    instances of Q are disjoint). This condition then follows.

are in positions labeled by J.)

A planar bicolored graph (or plabic graph ) is an undirected graph G drawn inside a disk
(and considered modulo homotopy)
plus n boundary vertices on the boundary of the disk,
labeled 1,‚Ä¶,n in clockwise order. 
The remaining internal vertices
are strictly inside the disk and are

single edge.

sentence:
Given a plabic graph G,
the trip T_i is the directed path which starts at the boundary vertex
i, and follows the ‚Äúrules of the road": it turns right at a
black vertex and   left at a white vertex.
Note that T_i  will also
end at a boundary vertex.  The decorated trip permutation œÄ_G
is the permutation such that œÄ_G(i)=j whenever T_i
ends at j.  Moreover, if there is a white (respectively, black)
boundary leaf at boundary vertex i, then œÄ_G(i)=i is a 
counterclockwise (respectively, clockwise) fixed point.

Two plabic graphs are called move-equivalent if they can be obtained
from each other by moves (M1)-(M3).  The move-equivalence class
of a given plabic graph G is the set of all plabic graphs which are move-equivalent
to G.
A leafless plabic graph without isolated components
is called reduced if there is no graph in its move-equivalence
class to which we can apply (R1).

sentence:
Given a plabic graph G with n boundary vertices,
start at each boundary
vertex i and label every edge along trip T_i with i.
After doing this for each boundary vertex,
each edge will be labeled by up to two numbers (between 1 and n).
If an edge is labeled by two numbers i<j,  write [i,j]
on that edge.

We say that a  plabic graph has the
resonance property , if after labeling edges as above,
the set E of edges incident to a given vertex  has
the following property:


  * there exist numbers i_1<i_2<‚Ä¶<i_m such that when
we read the labels of E,  we see the labels
[i_1,i_2],[i_2,i_3],‚Ä¶,[i_m-1,i_m],[i_1,i_m] appear in
clockwise order.

sentence:
[ The BCFW-bridge construction ]
Given a decorated permutation œÄ on n letters, which is not 
simply a decoration of the identity, we start by  choosing
a pair of adjacent positions i<j such that 
œÄÃÉ(i)<
œÄÃÉ(j), and 
i and j are not fixed points.
Here adjacent means that either
j=i+1, or i<j and every position h such that i<h<j is a fixed point.
We record the transposition œÑ= (ij) and swap the entries in positions
i and j in œÄÃÉ.  Any entries in the resulting permutation
which are fixed points are designated as frozen , and henceforth ignored.
We continue this process on the resulting affine permutation,
until the end result is a decoration of the identity.
Finally we use the sequence of transpositions œÑ as a recipe
for adding ‚Äúbridges," thereby constructing a plabic graph.

Let L=(V,D,C) be a CSP. A partial function p: V  D is an
instantiation . An instantiation p satisfies a
constraint if there exists a function h in the constraint, such
that h(x)=p(x) for all x‚àà V on which p is defined. An
instantiation is valid , if it satisfies all the constraints in C.
An instantiation defined on all variables is total . A valid,
total instantiation is a solution to L. The number of
solutions of L will be denoted by #L.

xy, D(x)‚äÜ D(y), and U(y)‚äÜ U(x). A linear extension L

one of the linear extensions.

if no pair of independent edges cross more than once.

sentence: For a graph G, let PG denote the set of pairs of independent edges of G. We will say that a subset A of PG is 2-realisable if there is a drawing of G in the plane for which each element in A cross an odd number of times, while  each element of PG\ A cross an even number of times. Further, we say that such a drawing 2-realises A.

(cf. Stanley <cit.>)
  For any word w=w_1‚Ä¶ w_m without repetition, define recursively its
  increasing binary tree (w) as follows:
  
  
  * if w is empty (i.e. m=0), then (w) is the empty binary tree;

    (w) is the binary tree whose root is labelled w_k, whose left
    subtree is (w_1‚Ä¶ w_k-1) and whose right subtree is (w_k+1‚Ä¶
    w_m).

sentence:
A plabic (or planar bicolored) graph
is an undirected graph G drawn inside a disk
(considered modulo homotopy)
with n boundary vertices on the boundary of the disk,
labeled 1,‚Ä¶,n in clockwise order, as well as some
colored internal vertices.
These internal vertices
are strictly inside the disk and are
colored in black and white. 
An internal vertex of degree one adjacent to a boundary vertex is a lollipop .
We will always assume that no vertices of the same color are adjacent, and that 
each boundary vertex i is adjacent to a single internal vertex.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Two plabic graphs are called move-equivalent if they can be obtained
from each other by moves (M1)-(M3).  The move-equivalence class
of a given plabic graph G is the set of all plabic graphs which are move-equivalent
to G.
A leafless plabic graph without isolated components
is called reduced if there is no graph in its move-equivalence
class to which we can apply (R1).

sentence:

a  trip T is a directed path which starts at
some boundary vertex
i, and follows the ‚Äúrules of the road": it turns (maximally) right at a
black vertex,  and (maximally) left at a white vertex.
 Note that T will also
end at a boundary vertex j; we then refer to this trip as
T_i ‚Üí j. Setting œÄ(i)=j for each such trip,
 we associate a (decorated) trip permutation
œÄ_G=(œÄ(1),‚Ä¶,œÄ(n)) to each reduced plabic graph G, where a fixed point œÄ(i)=i is colored white (black) if there is a white (black) lollipop at boundary vertex i.

Let G be a reduced plabic graph with b boundary vertices.
For each one-way trip T_i‚Üí j with i ‚â† j, we place the label j
 in every face which is to the left of T_i‚Üí j. If i=j (that is, i is adjacent to a lollipop), we place the label i 
in all faces if the lollipop is white and in no faces if the lollipop is black.
We then obtain a labeling ‚Ñ±(G)
of faces of G by subsets of [b] which
we call the target
labeling of G.  We identify each a-element subset of [b]
with the corresponding Pl√ºcker coordinate.

sentence:
Let G be a reduced plabic graph.  We associate a quiver Q(G) as follows.  The vertices of 
Q(G) are labeled by the faces of G.  We say that a vertex of Q(G) is frozen
if the 
corresponding face is incident to the boundary of the disk, and is mutable otherwise.
For each edge e in G which separates two faces, at least one of which is mutable, 
we introduce an arrow connecting the faces;
 this arrow is oriented so that it ‚Äúsees the white endpoint of e to the left and the 
black endpoint to the right‚Äù as it crosses over e.  We then remove oriented 2-cycles
from the resulting quiver, one by one, to get Q(G). See 
<ref>.

sentence:
Let G be an undirected graph.


  * A walk is an alternating sequence of vertices and edges x_1, e_1, x_2, e_2, ‚Ä¶, e_s-1, x_s such that e_i = {x_i, x_i+1} for all i = 1, ‚Ä¶, s-1. Such a walk is said to be closed if x_1 = x_s.

  * A walk is called a trail if its edges are distinct (while its vertices may repeat). A closed trail is called a circuit .

  * A walk is called a path if its edges and vertices are distinct (except possibly at x_1 = x_s). A closed path is called a cycle .

  * The length of a walk is the number of edges that the walk transverses through (including multiplicities). A walk is even (or odd ) if its length is an even (or odd) number.

sentence: Suppose we have a finite collection of arcs positioned around a circle of any radius so that no arc properly contains another.  We consider the starting point of an arc as the counterclockwise-most endpoint of the arc.  We can construct a digraph, which we call a proper circular arc digraph by assigning a vertex to each arc and having an edge from arc A to arc B if the starting point of arc B is contained in arc A.  The underlying undirected graph is called a proper circular arc graph .

sentence: Suppose we have a finite collection of intervals on the real line. We can associate a graph to this interval representation by letting each interval correspond to a vertex and allowing two distinct vertices to be adjacent if their corresponding intervals overlap.  This is called an interval graph .  If no interval properly contains another, this is called a proper interval graph .  If each interval has length 1, this is called a unit interval graph .

sentence: Let Œî be a normal (d-1)-pseudomanifold such that one of the vertex links, _Œî v, is a homology (d-2)-sphere. If a missing facet œÑ of _Œî v is also a missing face of Œî, then we define the Swartz operation on {v,œÑ} of Œî by first removing v, next adding œÑ, then coning off two remaining homology spheres S_1, S_2 with two new vertices v_1,v_2. (Here S_1, S_2 are the two homology spheres such that their connected sum by identifying the face œÑ is _Œî v.) If one of the two spheres, say S_1, forms the boundary of a missing facet of Œî‚à™{œÑ}, then we simply add this missing facet to Œî‚à™{œÑ} instead of coning off S_1 with v_1. The resulting complex is denoted by _v,œÑ(Œî). If the dimension of Œî is at least three, then iterating this process, we are able to add all missing facets of _Œî v to Œî. The resulting complex is denoted by _v(Œî).

sentence:
Let Œî be a d-dimensional simplicial complex. Assume that there is a vertex v‚àà V(Œî) such that _Œî v is an (r-1)-stacked polytopal (d-1)-sphere. If no interior face of (_Œî v)(r-1) is a face of Œî, then define the inverse stellar retriangulation on vertex v by
    	
    _v^-1(Œî)=(Œî\{v})‚à™(_Œî v)(r-1).
In other words, we replace the star of v with the ball (_Œî v)(r-1). It is easy to see that _v^-1(Œî) is PL-homeomorphic to Œî. Using the same argument as in Lemma <ref>, we prove the following result.

sentence:
Given a hypergraph G,
a hyperedge A ‚àà E(G) is said to be induced-bisected by a bicoloring X^S of a subset S ‚äÜ V(G),
if |A ‚à© X^S(+1)|=|A ‚à© X^S(-1)| ‚â† 0.


A set ùí≥={X^S_1,‚Ä¶, X^S_t} of t bicolorings is called an induced-bisecting family of order d for G if

	
  * each S_i ‚äÜ [n] has exactly d vertices, 1 ‚â§ i ‚â§ t, 2 ‚â§ d ‚â§ n, and
	
  * every non-trivial hyperedge A ‚àà E(G) is induced-bisected by at least one X^S_i, 1 ‚â§ i ‚â§ t.

Let Œ≤^d(G) denote the minimum cardinality of an induced-bisecting family of order d for hypergraph G.

sentence:
Let (H_0, H_i, L_i)^n be an ear decomposition of a trigraph H.
 We say that (H_0, H_i, L_i)^n is robust if for each 3-ear, say L_i,
 the descendant of I(L_i) is composed of at most 2 connected components. 
 Moreover, if the descendant is composed of two connected components, then one of them is an isolated vertex
 adjacent to two vertices in V(H_0).

sentence:
Let H be a trigraph, H_0 be an induced cycle of H and let  (H_0, H_i, L_i)^n
be an ear decomposition of H. 


  * We refer to a 2,3-ear as a base if its leaves are in H_0, as an up if one leaf belongs to H_0 and the other one to a base, as an antenna if exactly one leaf belongs to an up.

  * Let S be a set of disjoint paths of H on 3 vertices. We say that (H_0, H_i, L_i)^n 
admits H_0, S if the following three conditions hold.
(1) If L_i is a 3-ear, then L_i is either a base, or an up or, an antenna containing an element of S.
(2)¬†Each element of S is a subset of an antenna.
(3)¬†No 1-ear has both leaves in H_0 or one leaf in a base and second one in an up.

sentence:
A basic gadget ‚Ñ¨=‚Ñ¨(x,u) is a sequence E_1, E_2, E'_3, E_4, D_1, D_2, D_3 of short
ears which, considering the vertices named according to Figure¬†<ref>, are defined as follows:  

 
  (i) I(E_1)={a',w',b'}, I(E_2) ={a,w,b}, V(E'_3)={b,z,y,x}, V(E_4)={z, u, v, y},
 and the end vertices of E_1 and E_2 belong to H_0,
 
  (iii) D_1, D_2, D_3 are stars, {a', w, v} is the set of leaves of D_1, and each star
 D_2, D_3 has two leaves in H_0.
 Moreover, vertex w' is a leaf of D_2 and vertex a is a leaf of D_3.

Depending on the context, a basic gadget may also refer to the 
graph obtained by the union of the ears E_1, E_2, E'_3, E_4, D_1, D_2, D_3. 
In addition, we say that the path on vertex set {b,z,y} is the fixed path,
u is the replica and x is the joint of the basic gadget; 
whenever only the replica vertex u is specified, we denote by x_u the corresponding joint vertex.

sentence:
[Admits H_0, S]

Let H be a trigraph, H_0 be an induced cycle of H and let  (H_0, H_i, L_i)^n
be an ear decomposition of H. 


  * We refer to a 2,3-ear as a base if its leaves are in H_0, as an up if one leaf belongs to H_0 and the other one to a base, as an antenna if exactly one leaf belongs to an up.

  * Let S be a set of disjoint paths of H on 3 vertices. We say that (H_0, H_i, L_i)^n 
admits H_0, S if the following three conditions hold.
(1) If L_i is a 3-ear, then L_i is either a base, or an up or, an antenna containing an element of S.
(2)¬†Each element of S is a subset of an antenna.
(3)¬†No 1-ear has both leaves in H_0 or one leaf in a base and second one in an up.

sentence:
[Local exchange. Closure]

Let H be a trigraph, H_0 be an induced cycle of H and let S be a set of disjoint paths of H on 3 vertices. 
Let ‚Ñã=(H_0, H_i, L_i)^n  be an ear decomposition of H that admits H_0, S. 


  * A local exchange on the pair H, ‚Ñã
is an operation that produces a pair H', (H_0, H'_i, L'_i)^n of a trigraph with its ear decomposition (see Figure¬†<ref>) as follows:
Let L_i_0‚àà{L_1,‚Ä¶, L_n} be a 3-ear antenna with vertices a, w_1, w_2, w_3, b. 
Let (L_i_j)_j ‚àà [l] be a heel such that the leaves of L_i_1 are w_2, w_3,
and let u be the internal vertex of L_i_l that has the shortest distance (in the heel) to w_3. 
Further let L_k, L_m be ears such that w_1 is a leaf of L_k and u is a leaf of L_m
and assume {w_1,w'_1}, {u,u'} are edges of L_k, L_m, respectively. 
Then, H', L'_k, L'_m are obtained by deleting the edges {w_1,w'_1}, {u,u'} 
and adding the new edges {w_1,u'}, {u,w'_1}. The other ears do not change, namely L'_i=L_i for all i ‚àâ{k,m}.
Note that (H_0, H'_i, L'_i)^n admits H_0, S.

  * The closure of the pair H, ‚Ñã is the set of all pairs H',
‚Ñã', where H' is a trigraph and ‚Ñã' is an ear decomposition of H' admitting H_0, S,
such that H', ‚Ñã' are  obtained from H, ‚Ñã by a sequence of the following two operations: 
(1) a modification of the current ear decomposition to another one admitting H_0, S,  and (2) a local exchange on the current trigraph.

 and the end vertices of E_1 and E_2 belong to H_0,
 
  (iii) D_1, D_2, D_3 are stars, {a', w, v} is the set of leaves of D_1, and each star
 D_2, D_3 has two leaves in H_0.
 Moreover, vertex w' is a leaf of D_2 and vertex a is a leaf of D_3.

[Reduction process]
A reduction process of gadget ùí¢ is a  
of a subsequence ùí¢' of ùí¢^-1, so that

 
  (i) either ùí¢' = ùí¢^-1,

such that I(E_j-1) does not have correct reduction or I(E_j-1) is a cut-obstacle. 

If (i) holds, we say that the reduction process is complete .
Otherwise, we refer to it as j-incomplete .

An ear decomposition, say (G_0, G_i, P_i)^l, of G is super robust

the descendant of S is connected.

We will say that two graphs in pseudo-surfaces  G_1‚äÇŒ£_1 and  G_k‚äÇŒ£_k are  LV-equivalent if there is a sequence of graphs in pseudo-surfaces  G_1‚äÇŒ£_1, G_2‚äÇŒ£_2, ‚Ä¶, G_k‚äÇŒ£_k such that G_i‚äÇŒ£_i is obtained from  G_i-1‚äÇŒ£_i-1, or vice versa, by one of the following moves. 


  * Deleting an isolated vertex, that is not a pinch point, from a graph.

  * Deleting a component of the pseudo-surface that contains no edges of the graph. 

  * Connect summing two pseudo-surface components (away from any graph components), or identifying a vertex in each of them to form a pinch point. 

  * Replacing a region, with another pseudo-surface with boundary (so that it forms a region of a new graph in a pseudo-surface).

sentence:
[Peeling process and peeling sequences]
Given =(G,Œ∏) a valued digraph, we construct recursively two sequences: a sequence L=[x_1,x_2,‚Ä¶] of elements of V, and a sequence (_i=(G_i,Œ∏_i))_1‚â§ i of valued digraphs as follows. 


  * Let _1=.

  * If there is not any erasable vertex in _i, the process stop. Otherwise, choose x a vertex of G_i which is erasable in _i, and set x_i=x.


  * Let G_i+1 be the simple acyclic directed graph obtained by removing the vertex x_i in G_i and all the arcs of the form (z,x_i) or (x_i,z) in G_i.

  * Let Œ∏_i+1 be the OCV on G_i+1 such that Œ∏_i+1(y)=Œ∏_i(y)-1 if (y,x) is an arc of G_i, and Œ∏_i+1(y)=Œ∏_i(y) otherwise. Then set _i+1=(G_i+1,Œ∏_i+1) and iterate Step 2.


A sequence L coming from this process is called a peeling sequence of , and we denote by PS() the set of all peeling sequences of .

  * for all 1‚â§ i<j‚â§ n, if z_j ‚àà_z_i, then f(z_i)<f(z_j).

  * each element of ‚Ñ§/n‚Ñ§ appears at most once in the sequence;

  * if there exists p and q such that i_p=j and i_q=j+1, then q<p.

For any œâ‚ààA_n, a cyclically decreasing factorization of œâ is an expression of œâ as a product œâ=v_1v_2‚ãØ v_r such that:


  * each v_i ‚ààA_n is cyclically decreasing;

  * ‚Ñì(œâ)=‚Ñì(v_1)+‚ãØ+‚Ñì(v_r).

Finally, the affine Stanley symmetric function F_œâ associated with œâ is defined as

    F_œâ(x_1,x_2,‚Ä¶):=‚àë_œâ=v_1‚ãØ v_r x_1^‚Ñì(v_1)‚ãØ x_r^‚Ñì(v_r),

sentence:
A tropical curve G in an open subset U‚äÇ^n is a finite one-dimensional polyhedral complex in U satisfying the following conditions.
=5mm

  * G is closed in U as a topological subspace. We call the 0-dimensional faces of G vertices , and the one-dimensional faces of G edges . The set of vertices is denoted by V(G); the set of edges is denoted by E(G). There are two kinds of edges: those edges which have both endpoints in U are called internal edges ; while the rest are called unbounded edges .

  * Each vertex of G is at least 3-valent.

  * Each edge e is equipped with a weight w_e‚àà W parallel to the direction of e inside ^n. If w_e is k times a primitive integral vector, we call |k| the multiplicity of the edge e.

  * We require that the balancing condition holds, i.e. for any vertex v of G, we have ‚àë_e‚àã vw_e = 0, where the sum is taken over all edges containing v as an endpoint, and w_e is the representative of w_e which points outwards from v.

sentence:
Let A and B be alphabets and let H be a set of nonerasing morphisms from A^* to B^*.  An H-image of a word w=a_1‚Ä¶ a_n with a_i‚àà A is a word of the form

    h_1(a_1)‚Ä¶ h_n(a_n),

where h_i‚àà H (note that the h_i are not necessarily distinct).  Let u be a nonempty factor of some word v‚àà H(A)^+.  We say that w=a_1‚Ä¶ a_n is an H-preimage of u if there is an H-image h_1(a_1)‚Ä¶ h_n(a_n) of w that has u as a factor, and w is minimal in the sense that h_1(a_1)‚Ä¶ h_n-1(a_n-1) and h_2(a_2)‚Ä¶ h_n(a_n) do not have u as a factor.  The H-preimage of the empty word œµ is simply œµ.

sentence:
For a connected graph G=(V,E), say that a spanning tree T ‚äÇ E for G has an absorption order in G if one can
linearly order the union V ‚äî T of its vertices and edges in the following way:


  (i) The order begins with a vertex v_0 in V followed by an edge e_0 of T, such that
e_0 is the unique edge of T incident to v_0 (so v_0 is a leaf-vertex of T attached along the leaf-edge e_0).

  (ii)  For every other vertex v in V ‚àñ{v_0}, there exists an edge e={v,w}
such that w occurs earlier in the order than v, and the edge e either lies in E ‚àñ T or
occurs earlier in the order than v.

  (iii)  For every other edge e in T ‚àñ{e_0}, there exists a vertex v
incident to e which occurs earlier in the order than e,
and every other edge incident to v either lies in E ‚àñ T
or occurs earlier in the order than e.

sentence:
Let s be a positive integer, and let t‚àà{s-1, s}.
Let X={x_1,x_2,‚Ä¶,x_s} and Y={y_1,y_2,‚Ä¶,y_t} be ordered sets of real numbers.  We say that the set X interlaces the set Y from both sides , denoted X‚ãà Y, if t=s-1 and

    x_1<y_1<x_2<y_2<‚ãØ<x_s-1<y_t<x_s.

Note that the bow-tie symbol ‚ãà consists of a ‚Äútimes‚Äù symbol √ó in the middle and a bar at each side.  The left (resp., right) bar indicates that the smallest (resp., largest) number in the chain¬†(<ref>) is from the set¬†X. We say that the set X interlaces Y from the right , denoted X‚ãä Y, if either¬†X‚ãà Y or

    t=s

sentence:
A tree decomposition of a graph G is a tree T whose nodes are subsets of the vertices of G, satisfying the following properties:


  * Each vertex of G is contained in at least one node of T.

  * If two nodes of T both contain a given vertex v, then all nodes of the tree in the unique path between these two nodes must contain v as well.

  * If two vertices v and w are adjacent in G, then there is a node of T that contains both v and w.

The width of a tree decomposition is one less than the number of vertices in its largest node.  The treewidth (G) of a graph G is the minimum width among all possible tree decompositions of G.

A Euclidean square distinct difference configuration

distinct either in length or in slope.

where the c_j's are non-negative integers and c_‚Ñì-1 is non-zero. The word c_‚Ñì -1‚ãØ c_0 is called the normal U-representation of n and is denoted by _U(n). sentence:
We define ùöÇùööùöûùöäùöõùöéùöú‚äÇ (^2)^4 to be the set of all quadruples of vertices of squares in ^2 traversed in anticlockwise order; more explicitly, we have

    ùöÇùööùöûùöäùöõùöéùöú{ ((x,y), (x+a, y+b), (x+a-b, y+a+b), (x-b, y+a)): x,y,a,b ‚àà; (a,b) ‚â† (0,0) }.

By abuse of notation we refer to elements of ùöÇùööùöûùöäùöõùöéùöú as (non-degenerate) squares.
Thus we see that a set Œì‚äÇ^2 inscribes a square if and only if Œì^4 intersects ùöÇùööùöûùöäùöõùöéùöú.  We also form the closure 

    ùöÇùööùöûùöäùöõùöéùöú{ ((x,y), (x+a, y+b), (x+a-b, y+a+b), (x-b, y+a)): x,y,a,b ‚àà}

 in which the sidelength of the square is allowed to degenerate to zero; this is a four-dimensional linear subspace of (^2)^4.  A quadruple (Œ≥_1,Œ≥_2,Œ≥_3,Œ≥_4) of curves Œ≥_1,Œ≥_2,Œ≥_3,Œ≥_4  [t_0,t_1] ‚Üí^2 is said to traverse squares if one has (Œ≥_1(t), Œ≥_2(t), Œ≥_3(t), Œ≥_4(t)) ‚ààùöÇùööùöûùöäùöõùöéùöú for all t ‚àà [t_0,t_1]; note that we allow the square traversed to degenerate to a point.  Equivalently, (Œ≥_1,Œ≥_2,Œ≥_3,Œ≥_4) traverses squares if and only if there exist continuous functions x,y,a,b  [t_0,t_1] ‚Üí^2 such that

    Œ≥_1(t)    = (x(t), y(t)) 
    Œ≥_2(t)    = (x(t) + a(t), y(t) + b(t)) 
    Œ≥_3(t)    = (x(t) + a(t) - b(t), y(t) + a(t) + b(t)) 
    Œ≥_4(t)    = (x(t) - b(t), y(t) + a(t)).

sentence:
Let m=2,3, and for each 1 ‚â§ i ‚â§ m, let y_i,1, y_i,2‚àà [-‚àû,+‚àû] be extended reals.  We say that the pairs { y_i,1,  y_i,2} for i=1,‚Ä¶,m have non-crossing sums if the following axioms are obeyed:


  (i)  Either all of the y_i,1, y_i,2 avoid +‚àû, or they all avoid -‚àû. 

  (ii)  For any j_1,‚Ä¶,j_m ‚àà{1,2}, the sum y_1,j_1 + ‚Ä¶ + y_m,j_m (which is well defined by (i)) is non-zero.

  (iii)  One has the cancellation

    ‚àë_j_1,‚Ä¶,j_m ‚àà{1,2} (-1)^j_1+‚Ä¶+j_msgn( y_1,j_1 + ‚Ä¶ + y_m,j_m ) = 0.

or equivalently (by (ii))

    ‚àë_j_1,‚Ä¶,j_m ‚àà{1,2}:  y_1,j_1 + ‚Ä¶ + y_m,j_m > 0 (-1)^j_1+‚Ä¶+j_m = 0.

That is to say, there are as many positive sums y_1,j_1 + ‚Ä¶ + y_m,j_m > 0 with the index sum j_1+‚Ä¶+j_m even as there are positive sums y_1,j_1 + ‚Ä¶ + y_m,j_m > 0 with j_1+‚Ä¶+j_m odd (and similarly with ‚Äúpositive‚Äù replaced by ‚Äúnegative‚Äù).

Otherwise, we say that the pairs {y_i,1, y_i,2} for i=1,‚Ä¶,m have crossing sums .

sentence:
[Squares]
We define ùöÇùööùöûùöäùöõùöéùöú‚äÇ (^2)^4 to be the set of all quadruples of vertices of squares in ^2 traversed in anticlockwise order; more explicitly, we have

    ùöÇùööùöûùöäùöõùöéùöú{ ((x,y), (x+a, y+b), (x+a-b, y+a+b), (x-b, y+a)): x,y,a,b ‚àà; (a,b) ‚â† (0,0) }.

By abuse of notation we refer to elements of ùöÇùööùöûùöäùöõùöéùöú as (non-degenerate) squares.
Thus we see that a set Œì‚äÇ^2 inscribes a square if and only if Œì^4 intersects ùöÇùööùöûùöäùöõùöéùöú.  We also form the closure 

    ùöÇùööùöûùöäùöõùöéùöú{ ((x,y), (x+a, y+b), (x+a-b, y+a+b), (x-b, y+a)): x,y,a,b ‚àà}

 in which the sidelength of the square is allowed to degenerate to zero; this is a four-dimensional linear subspace of (^2)^4.  A quadruple (Œ≥_1,Œ≥_2,Œ≥_3,Œ≥_4) of curves Œ≥_1,Œ≥_2,Œ≥_3,Œ≥_4  [t_0,t_1] ‚Üí^2 is said to traverse squares if one has (Œ≥_1(t), Œ≥_2(t), Œ≥_3(t), Œ≥_4(t)) ‚ààùöÇùööùöûùöäùöõùöéùöú for all t ‚àà [t_0,t_1]; note that we allow the square traversed to degenerate to a point.  Equivalently, (Œ≥_1,Œ≥_2,Œ≥_3,Œ≥_4) traverses squares if and only if there exist continuous functions x,y,a,b  [t_0,t_1] ‚Üí^2 such that

    Œ≥_1(t)    = (x(t), y(t)) 
    Œ≥_2(t)    = (x(t) + a(t), y(t) + b(t)) 
    Œ≥_3(t)    = (x(t) + a(t) - b(t), y(t) + a(t) + b(t)) 
    Œ≥_4(t)    = (x(t) - b(t), y(t) + a(t)).

sentence:
[Area under a curve]  Let Œ≥ [t_0,t_1] ‚Üí^2 be a rectifiable curve, and write Œ≥(t) = (x(t),y(t)) for t ‚àà [t_0,t_1].  The area under Œ≥ , denoted by ‚à´_Œ≥ y dx, is defined to be the real number

    ‚à´_Œ≥ y dx ‚à´_t_0^t_1 y(t) dx(t)

where the integral on the right-hand side is in the Riemann-Stieltjes sense, that is to say the limit of ‚àë_i=0^n-1 y(s_i^*) (x(s_i+1) - x(s_i)) for any partition t_0 = s_0 < ‚Ä¶ < s_n = t_1 and s_i ‚â§ s_i^* ‚â§ s_i+1 as max_0 ‚â§ i ‚â§ n-1 |s_i+1 - s_i| goes to zero.

sentence:
[Infinitesimally inscribed squares]  Let L > 0.  A closed subset Œì of ùô≤ùö¢ùöï_L is said to inscribe infinitesimal squares if there exists a sequence of squares

    S_n = ((x_n,y_n), (x_n+a_n, y_n+b_n), (x_n+a_n-b_n, y_n+a_n+b_n), (x_n-b_n, y_n+a_n))

    ùöçùöíùöúùöù(S_n, Œì^4) = o(|a_n|+|b_n|)

as n ‚Üí‚àû.

sentence:

We say that the quadruplet (Œì_1, Œì_2, Œì_3, Œì_4) jointly inscribes a square if Œì_1 √óŒì_2 √óŒì_3 √óŒì_4 intersects ùöÇùööùöûùöäùöõùöéùöú_L, or equivalently if there exist x ‚àà/L and y,a,b ‚àà such that

sentence:
[Non-crossing sums]  Let m=2,3, and for each 1 ‚â§ i ‚â§ m, let y_i,1, y_i,2‚àà [-‚àû,+‚àû] be extended reals.  We say that the pairs { y_i,1,  y_i,2} for i=1,‚Ä¶,m have non-crossing sums if the following axioms are obeyed:


  (i)  Either all of the y_i,1, y_i,2 avoid +‚àû, or they all avoid -‚àû. 

  (ii)  For any j_1,‚Ä¶,j_m ‚àà{1,2}, the sum y_1,j_1 + ‚Ä¶ + y_m,j_m (which is well defined by (i)) is non-zero.

  (iii)  One has the cancellation

    ‚àë_j_1,‚Ä¶,j_m ‚àà{1,2} (-1)^j_1+‚Ä¶+j_msgn( y_1,j_1 + ‚Ä¶ + y_m,j_m ) = 0.

or equivalently (by (ii))

    ‚àë_j_1,‚Ä¶,j_m ‚àà{1,2}:  y_1,j_1 + ‚Ä¶ + y_m,j_m > 0 (-1)^j_1+‚Ä¶+j_m = 0.

That is to say, there are as many positive sums y_1,j_1 + ‚Ä¶ + y_m,j_m > 0 with the index sum j_1+‚Ä¶+j_m even as there are positive sums y_1,j_1 + ‚Ä¶ + y_m,j_m > 0 with j_1+‚Ä¶+j_m odd (and similarly with ‚Äúpositive‚Äù replaced by ‚Äúnegative‚Äù).

Otherwise, we say that the pairs {y_i,1, y_i,2} for i=1,‚Ä¶,m have crossing sums .

sentence:
Fix a partition Œª of length l(Œª), and positive integers k and N such that k‚â• l(Œª). An N-modular diagram of length k is the Ferrers diagram of Œª to which a zeroth column of length k has been added, such that all cells are labeled with an integer between 1 and N, all but the rightmost cell of any row are labeled  N, and the entries of any column are weakly decreasing from top to bottom. 

If the integer k is clear from the context, we will simply speak of an N-modular diagram . In particular,  in the proofs of the main theorems of this paper, we will make a repeated use of modular diagrams of partitions contained inside suitable rectangles, and the lengths of the zeroth columns will always coincide with the heights of the rectangles. Finally, we will simply say that a row is labeled i if its rightmost cell is labeled i.

A 3-planar graph (G, ) consists of a graph G and a family = {A_1, ‚Ä¶, A_k} of pairwise disjoint subsets of V(G) (allowing = ‚àÖ) such that


  * for 1‚â§ i‚â† j ‚â§ k, N(A_i)‚à© A_j=‚àÖ,

  * for 1 ‚â§ i ‚â§ k, |N(A_i)|‚â§ 3, and

  * if p(G, ) denotes the graph obtained from G by (for each i) deleting A_i and adding new edges joining every pair of distinct non-adjacent vertices in N(A_i), then p(G, ) can be drawn in a closed disc D with no pair of edges crossing such that, for each A_i with |N(A_i)| = 3, N(A_i) induces a facial triangle in p(G, ).

If, in addition, b_1, ‚Ä¶, b_n are some vertices in G such that b_i ‚àâ A_j for any A_j ‚àà and b_1, ‚Ä¶ ,b_n occur on the boundary of D in that cyclic order, 
then we say that (G, , b_1, ‚Ä¶, b_n) is 3-planar. We will say that such a drawing is a plane drawing of (G, , b_1, ‚Ä¶, b_n). We will say that (G, b_1, ‚Ä¶, b_n) is 3-planar if there exists a collection  so that (G, , b_1, ‚Ä¶, b_n) is 3-planar. If (G, ‚àÖ, b_1, ‚Ä¶, b_n) is 3-planar we will say that (G, b_1, ‚Ä¶, b_n) is planar .

sentence:
A strong placement game is a combinatorial game played on a graph which satisfies the following:


  (i) The starting position is the empty board.

  (ii) Players place pieces on empty spaces of the board according to the rules.

  (iii) Pieces are not moved or removed once placed.

  (iv) The rules are such that if it is possible to reach a position through a sequence of legal moves, then any sequence of moves leading to this position consists only of legal moves.

The Trivial placement game on a board is the placement game that has no additional rules.

If ‚àº is the equality relation, ùóÄ_=,L simply counts the number of words of length n occurring in L. If L=A^*, then ùóÄ_‚àº,A^*(n) counts the number of equivalence classes of ‚àº partitioning A^n.

sentence:
Let ‚àº be an equivalence relation over A^*. Since the quotient A^*/‚àº is well-defined, 
we thus define the complexity function of an infinite word ùê∞ with respect to ‚àº as

    ùóâ_‚àº,ùê∞:‚Ñï‚Üí‚Ñï, n‚Ü¶#(_ùê∞(n)/‚àº).

If ‚àº is the equality relation, then ùóâ_=,ùê∞ is the usual factor complexity counting the number of factors of length n occurring in ùê∞ <cit.>. The latter measure also leads to defining the topological entropy of ùê∞. For a comprehensive presentation, see Cassaigne and Nicolas'¬†chapter <cit.>. For instance, ùóâ_=,ùê∞ is in ùí™(n) for every automatic sequence ùê∞ <cit.>. For a pure morphic word ùê∞, a theorem of Pansiot <cit.> shows that the growth order of ùóâ_=,ùê∞ can only take five forms 1,n,nloglog n, nlog n,n^2. See the survey <cit.>.

Let Œ≥, g, g_c be the constants for which the assertion
of Theorem¬†<ref> holds and
let k, ‚Ñì>0 be integers.


  (i)
There exists
a function Œ≤=Œ≤(k,‚Ñì) with -14‚â§Œ≤‚â§ 2^7, for which

    C(k,k+‚Ñì)
    =2^-4 3^1/2 g      k^k+3‚Ñì/2-1/2(Œ≥^2e^3/2/3^3/2)^‚Ñì ‚Ñì^-3‚Ñì/2-3
       √óexp(Œ≤‚àö(‚Ñì ^3/k)
    +O(‚Ñì^2/k)+O(1/‚Ñì)).



  (ii) The number C^conn(k,k+‚Ñì)
of labeled connected complex planar graphs
with k vertices and k+‚Ñì edges is given by  a similar
formula, with g replaced by g_c.


  (iii) A graph chosen uniformly at random among all complex planar
 graphs with k vertices and k+‚Ñì edges has deficiency
 Œò(‚àö(‚Ñì^3/k)) and the core of size
(1+O(‚àö(‚Ñì/k))+O(1/‚àö(‚Ñì)))‚àö(3k‚Ñì).
In particular, if ‚Ñì=o(k^1/3),

 random among all complex planar graphs with k vertices and k+‚Ñì

 giant component of size  k-O(k/‚Ñì). Furthermore, each  small component has Œò(k/‚Ñì) vertices and

                        that V ‚äÇ V_t for a vertex t ‚àà V(T).

  * a down-retraction , if r(x) ‚â§ x for every x‚àà X,

sentence:
A signed permutation is a permutation of numbers from 1 to
n, where each number has a +or - sign.

sentence:
A reversal takes any consecutive part of a signed permutation
and change both the order of the numbers and the sign of each
number. It is also allowed that a reversal takes only one single
number from the signed permutations, in that case, it changes the sign
of this number.

sentence:
Given a graph G(V,E) with its vertices colored with black and
white. Any black vertex v can be pressed, which has the following
effect: (a) all neighbors of v change color, white neighbors become
black and vice versa , (b) all pair of neighbors of v change
connectivity, connected pairs become unconnected, unconnected ones
become connected, (c) and finally, v becomes a separated white
vertex. The aim of the game is to transform G into an all white,
empty graph.

sentence:
[Nilsequences] A 2-step nilmanifold is a homogeneous space G/Œì, where G is a nilpotent Lie groups of step at most 2, and Œì is a discrete cocompact subgroup.  A fundamental 2-step nilmanifold is one of the following three examples of a 2-step nilmanifold:


  *  G = and Œì =.

  *  G = ([ 1    ; 0 1  ; 0 0 1 ]) and Œì = ([ 1    ; 0 1  ; 0 0 1 ]).

  *  G = ([ 1    ; 0 1  ; 0 0 1 ]) and Œì = ([ 1    ; 0 1  ; 0 0 1 ]).

We place smooth metrics on each of these nilmanifolds; the exact choice of metric is not important. An elementary 2-step nilmanifold is a Cartesian product of finitely many fundamental 2-step nilmanifolds, with the product metric. Again, the exact convention for defining the product metric is not important.  An elementary 2-step nilsequence is a sequence of the form n ‚Ü¶ F(g^n x_0), where G/Œì is an elementary 2-step nilmanifold, F: G/Œì‚Üí is a Lipschitz function, g ‚àà G, and x_0 ‚ààŒì.

sentence:
A set S of ordered pairs of integers is called
  symmetric if whenever (r,s) ‚àà S, then (s,r) ‚àà S. A

  constant sum by saying that S is a stripe of rank m.
  A stripe S is convex if the projection
  { r : (r,s) ‚àà S } is a set of consecutive integers.

sentence:
Let T be a tree.

occurring as induced subgraphs of¬†T, that covers all the vertices of¬†T.

  (b)
The path cover number of¬†T, P(T),
is the minimum number of paths occurring in a path cover of¬†T.

  (c)

say Q_1, Q_2,‚Ä¶,Q_P(T).
An extra edge is an edge of¬†T that is incident to vertices on two distinct Q's.
Clearly there are exactly P(T)-1 extra edges.

sentence:
The Michigan driving rule resolves each node of E(T) according to the following two cases:

    
  * If a ‚â• b, d ‚â§ c, the leftmost b drivers from the west turn left without crossing routes with each other. The remaining a-b drivers go straight, without crossing routes. Finally, all d drivers coming from the south turn right, without crossing routes with each other or with drivers coming from the west.
    
  * If a ‚â§ b, d ‚â• c, all a drivers from the west turn left without crossing routes with each other. The leftmost b-a drivers from the south go straight without crossing routes with each other or any west-coming drivers. Finally, the remaining c drivers coming from the south turn right without crossing routes.

sentence:
The Boston driving rule resolves each node of E(T) according to the following two cases:

    
  * If a ‚â• c, d ‚â§ b, the leftmost a-c drivers from the west turn left without crossing routes with each other. The remaining c drivers go straight without crossing routes with each other. Finally, all d drivers coming from south go straight, without crossing routes with each other, but crossing the routes of all other drivers. 
    
  * If a ‚â§ c, d ‚â• b, all a drivers from the west go straight without crossing routes with each other. The leftmost b drivers from the south go straight, without crossing routes with each other but crossing the routes of all west-coming drivers. Finally, the remaining d-b drivers coming from south turn right, without crossing routes with each other but crossing the routes of all west-coming drivers.

sentence:
[Weak separation rule]
Subsets I and J are weakly separated if at least one of the following holds:

  
  * |I| ‚â• |J| and J-I can be partitioned into a disjoint union J-I = J' ‚äî J‚Äù so that J' ‚â∫ I-J ‚â∫ J‚Äù,
  
  * |I| ‚â§ |J| and I-J can be partitioned into a disjoint union I-J = I' ‚äî I‚Äù so that I' ‚â∫ J-I < I‚Äù.

sentence:
[Non-crossing paths]

Paths p and q are non-crossing if p always lies to the northwest of q, or always lies to the southeast of q.
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Non-kissing paths]
Paths p and q are non-kissing if p and q leave every proper common part in same direction by which they entered.
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

Finally, the remaining c drivers coming from the south turn right without crossing routes.

sentence:
[Solid paths]
A path p in L is solid if it does one of the following: 

  
  * p moves east (possibly zero  distance), then moves north until it cannot do so any longer, then it moves east (possibly zero distance) until it hits a sink,
  
  * p moves north (possibly zero distance), then moves east until it cannot do so any longer, then it moves north (possibly zero distance) until it hits a sink.

sentence:
[Accurate sampling sequence]  Let k ‚â• 1, let V be a finite-dimensional vector space, let f: V ‚Üí be a bounded function, and let

    0= H_0 < H_1 < H_2 < H_3 < ‚Ä¶

be a sequence of integers (or ‚Äúscales‚Äù).  We define an accurate sampling sequence for f of degree k and at scales H_1,H_2,‚Ä¶ to be an infinite sequence of vectors

    v_1, v_2, v_3, ‚Ä¶‚àà V

    0 ‚â§ r_0 < r_1 < ‚Ä¶ < r_k

of scales and every Lipschitz function G: ^{0,1}^k √ó^H_r_0‚Üí, we have

    ‚à´_V | G_f,r_0,r_1,‚Ä¶,r_k - G_f,r_0 | ‚â§G_/r_1

    G_f,r_0,r_1,‚Ä¶,r_k(x) := _a‚Éó_1 ‚àà^H_r_1, ‚Ä¶, a‚Éó_k ‚àà^H_r_k 
    G( (f(x+œâ¬∑ u + b‚Éó¬∑v‚Éó_0))_œâ‚àà{0,1}^k, b‚Éó‚àà^H_r_0 ),

where 

    u = (a‚Éó_1 ¬∑v‚Éó_1,‚Ä¶ ,a‚Éó_k ¬∑v‚Éó_k) ;    v‚Éó_j=(v_1,‚Ä¶, v_H_r_j),  j=0,‚Ä¶, k,

and 

    G_f,r_0(x) := _h_1 ‚àà V, ‚Ä¶, h_k ‚àà V 
    G( (f(x+œâ¬∑ h  + b‚Éó¬∑v‚Éó_0))_œâ‚àà{0,1}^k, b‚Éó‚àà^H_r_0 ),

where h =(h_1,‚Ä¶,h_k).

sentence:
[Furstenberg universal space]
Let X := ^^œâ be the space of functions Œ∂: ^œâ‚Üí.  With the product topology, this is a compact metrisable space, with Borel œÉ-algebra .  It has a continuous action h ‚Ü¶ T_h of the additive group ^œâ, defined by the formula

    T_h Œ∂(x) := Œ∂(x+h).

We let (X)^T be the space of all Borel probability measures Œº on X which are invariant with respect to this action; note that = (X,,Œº,(T_h)_h ‚àà^œâ) is a ^œâ-system for any Œº‚àà(X)^T.  If Œº^(n)‚àà(X)^T is a sequence of such measures, and Œº‚àà(X)^T is another measure, we say that Œº^(n) converges vaguely to Œº if we have

for all continuous functions œï: X ‚Üí.

sentence:

sentence:
<cit.>
An oriented matroid  of rank d is a pair (E,œá) consisting of a finite set E
and a chirotope œá: E^d ‚Üí{-1,0,1} that satisfies the following properties:


  (B1') The map œá is alternating, i.e.,
for any permutation œÉ of [d] and any y_1,‚Ä¶,y_d ‚àà E, we have
 
    œá(y_œÉ(1),‚Ä¶,y_œÉ(d)) = (œÉ) ¬∑œá(y_1,‚Ä¶,y_d),

where (œÉ) is the sign of œÉ.
Moreover, the d-subsets {y_1, ‚Ä¶, y_d} of E such that œá(y_1, ‚Ä¶, y_d) ‚â† 0 are the bases of a matroid on E.

  (B2‚Äù') For any v_1, v_2, v_3, v_4, y_3,y_4, ‚Ä¶,y_d ‚àà E,


if œµ:=œá(v_1,v_2,y_3,y_4,‚Ä¶,y_d)  
¬∑œá(v_3,v_4,y_3,y_4,‚Ä¶,y_d) ‚àà{-1,1},

    œá(v_3,v_2,y_3,y_4,‚Ä¶,y_d)  
    ¬∑œá(v_1,v_4,y_3,y_4,‚Ä¶,y_d)    = œµ   or

    ¬∑œá(v_1, v_3,y_3,y_4,‚Ä¶,y_d)    = œµ.


We consider (E,œá) to be the same oriented matroid
as (E,-œá).

An n-step half-space walk (all points after the first one are on the right of the line, parallel to the x-axis passing through it) is a SAW, whose x-axis coordinates of the points satisfy the following inequality:

 for all i=1, 2,‚Ä¶, n.

sentence:
A hierarchy for a rectangle R , is a pair ‚Ñã = (G_‚Ñã, {R_u}_u ‚àà V(G_‚Ñã)), where G_‚Ñã is a finite directed rooted tree  with all edges directed away from the root and with maximum out-degree 3, together with a collection of rectangles {R_u}_u ‚àà V(G_‚Ñã) such that 


  * if r is the root of G_‚Ñã, then R_r = R,

  * if u ‚Üí v in G_‚Ñã, then R_u ‚äá R_v,

  * if u has three children, then at least one child has as its corresponding rectangle a single site,

  * if u has two or three children and at least one child v has short(R_v) >2, then R_u is internally spanned by the rectangles corresponding to its children.

Vertices with out-degree 0 are called seeds , vertices with out-degree 1 are called normal and vertices with out-degree 2 or 3 are called splitters .

sentence:
Given an initial infection X of R, the hierarchy ‚Ñã is said to occur (with respect to X) iff 

	
  * for every seed u, if the short side of R_u is the horizontal side then in every 4 adjacent columns in the the rectangle R_u, there are at least 2 initially infected sites within distance 2 (similarly for sets of 4 adjacent rows if the short side of R_u is vertical),
	
  * for every normal vertex u with u ‚Üí v ‚àà E(G_‚Ñã), the event D(R_v, R_u) holds,  

and these events occur disjointly.

For any rectangle R_u let J(R_u) be the event, as above, that in every 4 adjacent columns, there are at least 2 initially infected sites within distance 2 if the short side of R_u is horizontal and similarly for set of 4 adjacent rows if the short side of R_u is vertical.

sentence:
Suppose that f=X_1+‚Ä¶ +X_m and there is no X_i whose factors are a subset of another product's factors. 
The Iterated Consensus , IT (X_1, ‚Ä¶ ,X_m)  
is defined as follows. Starting with X_2, compute the consensus of each product with each prior product. For each valid consensus result X,


  * If the factors in X are a proper subset of the factors 
in any other product(s) on the list, remove the product(s). 

  * If the factors of any X_k on the list are a subset of the factors of X, discard X.  

  * If no X_k is a subset of X, append X to the list.

sentence:
A Boolean function f is called positive (also known as  positive monotone or increasing ) 
if f(x) = 1 
and xy imply f(y)=1.

sentence:
A Boolean function f on B^n is called a threshold function if there exist
n weights w_1, ‚Ä¶, w_n ‚àà‚Ñù and a threshold t ‚àà‚Ñù
such that, for all (x_1, ‚Ä¶, x_n) ‚àà B^n,

    f(x_1, ‚Ä¶, x_n) = 0 ‚àë_i=1^n w_i x_i ‚â§ t.

sentence:
A Boolean function f is called read-once if it can be represented by a Boolean formula using the operations of conjunction, disjunction, and negation in which every variable appears at most once.
We say that such a formula is a read-once formula for f.
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O

sentence:
A read-once function f is linear read-once ( lro )
if it is either a constant function, or it can be represented by a nested formula
defined recursively as follows:

	
  * both literals x and x are nested formulas;
	
  * x  t, x  t, x t, x t are nested formulas,
	where x is a variable and t is a nested formula that contains neither x, nor x.

sentence:

In this case we also say that S specifies f in the class  ‚Ñ±.
The minimal cardinality of a specifying set for f in ‚Ñ± is called the 
specification number of f (in ‚Ñ±) and denoted œÉ_‚Ñ±(f).

sentence:

there exists a function g ‚àà‚Ñã_n such that g(x) ‚â† f(x) and
g(y) = f(y) for every y‚àà B^n, y‚â†x.

sentence:
Suppose Œ£={a_1<a_2< ‚Ä¶<a_s} is an ordered alphabet. The Parikh matrix mapping , denoted Œ®_Œ£, is the monoid morphism

    Œ®_Œ£Œ£^*‚Üí‚Ñ≥_s+1

defined as follows:

if Œ®_Œ£(a_q)=(m_i,j)_1‚â§ i,j‚â§ s+1, then m_i,i=1 for each 1‚â§ i‚â§ s+1, m_q,q+1=1 and all other entries of the matrix Œ®_Œ£(a_q) are zero. 
Matrices of the form  Œ®_Œ£(w) for w‚ààŒ£^* are called Parikh matrices .

sentence:
Suppose Œ£={a_1<a_2< ‚Ä¶<a_s} is an ordered alphabet.
Two words w,w'‚ààŒ£^* are M-equivalent , denoted w‚â°_M w', iff Œ®_Œ£(w)=Œ®_Œ£(w').
A word w‚ààŒ£^* is M-ambiguous iff there exists some distinct word w'‚ààŒ£^* M-equivalent to w. Otherwise, w is said to be M-unambiguous .

sentence:
A Thue system is an ordered pair (Œ£, R), where Œ£ is an ordered alphabet[Although unnecessary in this definition, the alphabet is assumed to be ordered out of convenience and compatibility with the next definition.] and ‚àÖ‚â† R‚äÜ{ (y,y') | y,y' ‚ààŒ£^*  and  y‚â† y' }. 
Each element (y,y') of R is associated with two rewriting rules of the Thue system, 
which are suggestively denoted by y‚Üí y' and y'‚Üí y. 
Suppose w,w'‚ààŒ£^*. We say that w transforms directly into w', denoted w‚Üí_R w', using the rewriting rule y‚Üí y' iff 

    w=xyz   and  w'=xy'z  for some  x,z ‚ààŒ£^*.
 
We say w transforms into w', denoted w‚áí_R w', iff 
there exist w_0,w_1, ‚Ä¶,w_n‚ààŒ£^* such that

    w=w_0 ‚Üí_R w_1 ‚Üí_R w_2 ‚Üí_R ‚Ä¶‚Üí_R w_n=w'.

By definition, w ‚áí_R w for every w‚ààŒ£^*.

sentence:
A Thue system (Œ£,R) 
is Parikh sound

sentence:
A Parikh rewriting system is a triple ùîì=(Œ£,R, C ), where Œ£={a_1<a_2<‚Ä¶<a_s} is an ordered alphabet of size at least two, (Œ£,R) is a Thue system such that each rewriting rule preserves the Parikh vector, and C‚äÜ{  a_i,j|   1‚â§ i< j ‚â§ s }. The elements of C are called the counters .
Suppose w, w'‚ààŒ£^*. We say that w transforms into w', denoted w‚áí_ùîì w', iff 
| w|_c =| w'|_c for all c‚àà C and w‚áí_R w'.
Two Parikh rewriting systems ùîì and ùîî are equivalent iff ‚áí_ùîì=‚áí_ùîî.

We say that ùîì is complete
